Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: III: Data Collection and Risk Evaluation Learning in Identifying High Risk Ebola Subpopulations for the Intervention and Prevention of Large-scale Ebola Virus Spreading

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The 2014 Ebola epidemic is the largest in history, affecting multiple countries in West Africa, and now impacting the US and other countries worldwide. The US Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and partners are taking precautions to prevent the further spread of Ebola within the United States. There is a lack of public understanding of the risks associated with Ebola; witness the inconsistently applied local responses (such as quarantines) that do not match CDC recommendations. This project will develop technology to enable individuals to evaluate risks associated with their own past and planned activities and travel. This will both enable those at risk to take appropriate action, and reduce unwarranted demand on the healthcare system by reassuring those whose activities have not placed them at risk. This project will use data gathered from the CDC and other public sources to develop risk models, and develop a mobile app that will use this data along with the user's own location and activity history and plans to report individual risk to the user. An individual's data never leaves their own device, ensuring personal privacy. The resulting lessons learned will ease the process of developing similar individualized risk assessment tools for future epidemics, providing long-term benefits beyond the Ebola virus epidemic.

The research will address three main issues. The first is focused crawling of structured (CDC Contact Tracing reports) and unstructured (social media, web blogs) information on time, location, and activities of Ebola patients. A second research challenge is patient activity modeling: Given the returned information, developing a time/space/activity model determining the risk of the patient acting as a transmission agent. Finally, the project will develop a mobile app that tracks time, location, and activities of the mobile device user, and retrieves the patient activity models developed from public data to determine if the user is at risk of infection. This is a complex problem, as the data may be non-specific and require inferential techniques to estimate risk (e.g., being in the same time/location as a transmission agent poses very different risk if the location is a sports stadium as opposed to a restaurant); the project will develop ontologies for activities to use in estimating risk. The project will use expert opinion to seed regression models for risk assessment. Lessons learned from this project will also identify challenges for future research in information integration, risk analysis, machine learning, and privacy preserving technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Kansas received funds from NSF to support quick-response research in the pursuit of better intervention and prevention of large-scale Ebola virus outbreak in the United States of America. The objective of this project is to perform research on mining social media and developing risk analytics to identify high-risk subpopulations of Ebola virus infection. Outcomes of the project include a mobile App with two essential functions, Ebola Risk Assessment and Ebola Related News Update, and learning algorithms supporting the proposed system, including an online lifelong multi-task learning algorithm and a multi-view multi-task multi-label learning algorithm. Through Ebola Related News Update, we collect the Ebola-related news and push the information to the mobile App. Detailed information regarding activities of confirmed Ebola patients is pushed to the App periodically, so that the App can compute a composite score based on the known Ebola patients’ information and the geographical locations of the App user.

For better risk prediction, we have performed research on a group of advanced machine learning techniques such as online multi-task learning and multi-view learning, which help us integrate data from different sources. For multi-task learning, we have worked on structure discovery of lifelong multi-task learning, which is a new direction in machine learning. We proposed a novel direction of handling structure learning in lifelong multi-task learning, by learning functions to model the task relationships. We have also developed a cost-sensitive learning formalization to formalize task partition as a supervised learning problem and provided a solution to the related optimization problem. To the best of our knowledge, we are the first group that developed a functional representation of the structures among multiple tasks for online learning. For multi-view learning, we have developed a novel multi-task multi-view multi-label (MTVL) learning algorithm that adopts a multilinear factor analysis technique to handle task-view-label interactions. These algorithms are applicable to a wide range of problems in data mining and machine learning, such as image annotation, robotics, automated machines, etc.

Prevention and intervention of Ebola virus infection is of great importance to our society. In this project, we aim to demonstrate the power of predictive analytics and location-awareness computing in preventing the pandemics. Our system is applicable to other type of pandemics including Avian influenza and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS). This project also demonstrates the capacity of App development in health informatics domains. The informatics tools that we have developed are applicable to a wide range of problem in predictive modeling. This enables timely and reliable information dissemination and risk assessment of epidemic diseases of concern, and greatly reduces unnecessary social anxiety about potential outbreaks.  This project is highly interdisciplinary. It offers hands-on experience for training graduate and undergraduate students in interdisciplinary research where informatics approaches meet epidemiology.
